Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: The biggest current issue with GPU mining VRSC is PCIe bandwidth. Depending on setup, the hashrate of a 1080Ti ranges anywhere from 2-145 MH/s. GPU slotted direct to 16x in board is best (and even an unpowered 16x riser will drop rate some) and 1x-16x riser slotted in 1x gen2 port is the worst.

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: board, slot, power, CPU, and w/out riser(s) all play a big role in what a card does with Verus

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: best results I had on my z170-pro was with only 1 1080Ti and it was direct in slot

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: because of how the board is laned, just the act of having 2 cards on that board drops card0 by 31% (from 145 to 101) ðŸ˜¦

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this is good news for CPU miners

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and also it benefits small time GPU miners with just a few cards in a normal setup, instead of crazy riser monstrosity setups. Those big GPU farms won't switch to Verus

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but a few smalltime GPU people with cards that are almost worthless, sounds like we get a few of them

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: ya, my i7 6700k is ~ on par with a 1080Ti on this board if I have 2 Tis on it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: People might not build new GPU rigs just for Verus, but they will repurpose old ones

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: my local craiglists is about 40% people selling old GPU mining rigs, it's crazy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I didn't think anybody around here knew what mining was

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
CPU has a big impact on how well the GPU does, too
i7 + 1080TI kicks ass of i5 + 1080Ti

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: most "re-purposed" GPU rigs will likely need a CPU upgrade because of the transfer demands of Verus

Content: most "CPU only coins" are "CPU only coins" because no one has been assed to create a way to send the instruction set to a GPU

Content: well, pretty much all it does is dump the instruction set to the GPU, beyond that, it's RPC miner like most any other

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I have a question about z9 minis and running znomp. Does it really make sense to run a znomp instance for just one z9 mini? Is it just to save the pool fee, or are their more reasons relating to vardiff not being set correctly for ASICs?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: luckpool has an asic port: https://luckpool.org/getting_started

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the znomp docs itself say "setting this up is more than a full time job", so does it really make sense to run for one or a few z9s? I can see if you have a big farm like @ComputerGenie then it makes sense

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: lern me good, genie of the computer

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
@dukeleto 
1) The main thing is how much you support decentralization; pools = centralized
2) The "full time" thing came from NOMP and the ability to set it up and run a public pool; not anything to do with solo
3) Do you enjoy donating 1-3% of your currency to some random stranger so that you don't have to spend an hr or 2 setting up your own stuff?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie it all comes down to the real estimate of time for 3, and ongoing maintenance

Content: luckpool's fee is 0.5%, too ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: If I ever experience my first bout of "ongoing maintenance", then I might be able to address that part

Content: I like the idea of solo mining, if znomp was trivial, i wouldn't even ask. But I have heard many people complain about it being fragile and needing constant babysitting. Maybe that is not the case
